Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Expectation2: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation2: The build is stalled because no one can proceed until their core module is complete
Story: I sat at the dinner table, half-listening as my family tossed around ideas for our weekend together. My younger brother’s eyes lit up as he described a hiking trail he wanted us all to try, and my mom smiled, nudging me to join in. “You’ll come, right? We haven’t all been together in ages,” she said, her voice hopeful. I nodded, but my mind was elsewhere. My phone buzzed with another message from my project manager: “Any update on the module? The team’s waiting.” I was the only one who could finish the core piece, and without it, the entire build was at a standstill. I could feel the weight of my team’s expectations pressing down on me, knowing they were counting on me to deliver. At the same time, I saw the anticipation in my family’s faces, wanting me to be present, to laugh and share in the plans. My heart twisted as I tried to balance the pull of both worlds, feeling like I was letting someone down no matter what I chose.
